thread.title: A-plus: Windjammers finish first season in Class A undefeated
thread.title_full: A-plus: Windjammers finish first season in Class A undefeated

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Mark Haskell)
title: A-plus: Windjammers finish first season in Class A undefeated
text:
A-plus: Windjammers finish first season in Class A undefeated Camden Hills to compete in KVAC Class A title game Oct. 22 By Mark Haskell | Oct 18, 2015 
Rockport — Veteran Camden Hills girls soccer coach Meredith Messer did not seem fazed in August as she prepared her Windjammers for their first foray into the Class A ranks. 
With the regular season now in the rear view mirror, it is clear why — the Windjammers are very, very good. 
Camden Hills, after years of top-tier finishes in Class B, made its presence felt in Class A this season as the Windjammers finished with an unblemished 13-0-1 mark and are the top-ranked team in Class A North. 
The team wrapped its regular season with a 2-1 win at Mount Ararat of Topsham on Thursday, Oct. 15. 
Now, the Windjammers will look ahead to the Kennebec Valley Athletic Conference Class A championship game on Wednesday, Oct. 22, where they will play Bangor (11-1-2) at 6 p.m at Lawrence High School in Fairfield. 
Camden Hills earned a 4-1 road victory over the Rams Sept. 22 — Bangor's lone loss of the season. 
The Windjammers, who averaged 5.8 goals this season, outscored opponents 81-11 through 14 games. 
"It is really special for the team," coach Messer said of the fact the Windjammers ended unbeaten in Class A. "We knew we could compete but this was unexpected. We have enjoyed the challenge of 'A' and have worked hard as a team to be ready for the season. Now we are concentrating on our postseason goals." 
Windjammers clip Eagles' wings 
In the team's regular season finale against Mount Ararat, sisters Izzy Gutheinz and Emma Gutheinz netted goals, while Taylor Johnson had one assist. 
"The girls were very composed during the last two minutes of the game,” said coach Messer. “This was a game where there was a lot of pressure on the ball. The girls really stayed together and were committed to our style of play. In the end we were successful because we possessed the ball from the back to the front. I was very proud of their conduct, sportsmanship and performance." 
The Eagles put three forwards up top in the second half in an attempt to get on the scoreboard, but “Brynne Wrona did a fantastic job eliminating breakaways in the second half,” said coach Messer, who added that Grace Blackwell, Claire Pierce and Bryn Anderson also were paramount to the team's success on the defensive side of the ball against Mtount Ararat. 
Anna Manuel scored the lone goal for the Eagles. 
Jana Spieker made six saves in goal for the Windjammers. Camden Hills held a 12-7 edge in shots and 6-1 advantage in corner kicks.
